title: Occupational Noise-Induced Hearing Loss in a Zumba Instructor
chief_complaint: I have noticed intermittent buzzing in both ears after listening to music with headphones for long periods, but it usually goes away after a few minutes.

problem_summary.onset: Referral in August 2016; symptoms noted intermittently prior to this.
problem_summary.course: Stable hearing thresholds between June and December 2016.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral noise exposure; Left ear shows specific audiometric notch.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent bilateral tinnitus ('buzzing') after noise exposure.
problem_summary.functional_impact: None reported; patient communicates well in groups and noisy environments.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Referred by a friend; initially low self-efficacy regarding hearing protection despite positive attitude.

history.present_illness: Patient reports intermittent buzzing after headphone use. Works as a Zumba instructor (2 years, 6 classes/week).
history.otologic_history: Negative history of otologic diseases. Excellent general health.
history.noise_exposure_history: Zumba instructor for 2 years; classes up to 100 participants; music levels can reach >90 dBA. Also uses headphones for long periods.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally with a specific notch in the left ear at 6000 Hz.

numeric_results.Left_Ear_Thresholds: All frequencies ≤ 15 dB HL except 6000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores in both ears.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral reflexes within normal limits for 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: DPOAEs: Right ear normal except 3.5k and 6.25k Hz. Left ear reduced amplitude/absent between 4750-6500 Hz. TOAEs: Normal in both ears.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) showed normal absolute and interpeak latencies for Waves I, III, and V.

history.present_illness: Follow-up visit to monitor hearing status.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: No change in hearing thresholds compared to previous visit.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: DPOAEs repeated; similar pattern of low response amplitude across selected frequencies observed in both ears.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Knowledge, Attitudes, and Behavior (KAB) questionnaire administered.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally, with the exception of a distinct noise-induced notch at 6,000 Hz (30 dB HL) in the left ear. Speech recognition is excellent (100%) in quiet. While pure-tone thresholds are largely normal, DPOAE testing reveals reduced amplitudes in the high frequencies (4-8 kHz range), particularly in the left ear, suggesting early outer hair cell dysfunction consistent with noise exposure before it is fully evident on the audiogram.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows normal hearing in the right ear, but a small 'notch' in the left ear at a high pitch, which is a classic sign of early noise damage.
The 'buzzing' (tinnitus) you experience after headphone use is a warning sign from your ears that they are being overexposed.
Even though you hear well now, the specialized tests (OAEs) show some strain on the hair cells in your inner ear.
As a Zumba instructor, you are at high risk. We recommend high-fidelity 'musician's earplugs' which lower the volume without muffling the music or your voice.
It is crucial to wear hearing protection during every class to prevent this notch from deepening or spreading to other pitches.
notes_for_actor: You are a fit, healthy 27-year-old Zumba instructor.
You are generally positive and cooperative but initially don't feel you have a 'problem' because you hear fine in daily life.
You might be skeptical that you need earplugs because you need to hear the music beat and your students clearly.
You admit to using headphones for long periods and feeling a 'buzz' afterwards, but you've dismissed it as temporary until now.
